Comment: Depends on who you ask.  Ukraine says Russia promised territorial integrity when Ukraine gave up its nukes.  Russia says Ukraine violated that agreement first by seeking NATO membership.  Your mistake (based on your friend's erroneous black-and-white claim) is assuming that a clear case can be made that a diplomatic promise is broken.  First, no one really thinks a "diplomatic promise" is truly binding -- it's assumed that nations will break their promises when they decide it is in their interest to do so.  They are assumed to be kind of like white lies in the first place.  Second, when it comes to "diplomatic promises," there is rarely a clear, black and white case of "breaking" the promise.  Hitler invading Russia in 1941 is a pretty clear case, but those are few and far in between, at least in modern times.  Almost always the alleged promise breaker will claim the other side broke it first.  And sometimes even set up a false flag operation to support the claim.  So your friend's claim is oversimplistic.  Don't fall prey to his error.
